description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) is designed to be an entry point into the world of Microsoft certifications, validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation while focusing on the knowledge required for the 98-368: MTA Mobility and Devices Fundamentals Exam. One will also focus on desktops, laptops, tablets, cell phones and other devices typically used by an end user because when one first transitions over to IT, one will typically be starting in a role as help desk or desktop support and will need to identify and resolve the issues of such devices. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Mobility and Devices Fundamentals - 98-368
subtitle: Mobility and Devices Fundamentals

episodes.description: MTA validates building-block technology concepts and helps students explore, discover and pursue successful careers in Information Technology (IT) in an exciting and rewarding way! As the first step in the Microsoft Technology Certification Series, this new, entry-level certification provides students with confidence, credibility, and differentiation.
episodes.title: MTA 98-368 - Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.089 --> 00:00:07.015
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.015 --> 00:00:10.212
In this segment,
we're gonna take a look at the MTA exam,

3
00:00:10.212 --> 00:00:12.380
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

4
00:00:12.380 --> 00:00:14.511
Right?
Is that right, Don, the MTA?

5
00:00:14.511 --> 00:00:16.225
[LAUGH]
>> That's absolutely right.

6
00:00:16.225 --> 00:00:18.401
The MTA,
the Microsoft Technology Associate,

7
00:00:18.401 --> 00:00:21.970
is designed to be a entry point into
the world of Microsoft certifications.

8
00:00:21.970 --> 00:00:26.910
If you're just getting started in IT the
MTA is a great place to get started out.

9
00:00:26.910 --> 00:00:31.575
It's not gonna hit you with crazy over the
top objectives that you have no chance of

10
00:00:31.575 --> 00:00:32.260
learning.

11
00:00:32.260 --> 00:00:34.890
It's gonna to start you off with
the basics, the fundamentals.

12
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:36.850
And that makes it a very
valuable certification to get,

13
00:00:36.850 --> 00:00:38.910
especially if you're a career changer.

14
00:00:38.910 --> 00:00:43.653
Well in this series, we're gonna be
covering the MTA specifically designed for

15
00:00:43.653 --> 00:00:45.057
mobility and devices.

16
00:00:45.057 --> 00:00:46.763
And what does that mean?

17
00:00:46.763 --> 00:00:48.442
Right?
Cuz there's a lot of different MTAs that

18
00:00:48.442 --> 00:00:48.982
are out there.

19
00:00:48.982 --> 00:00:53.257
Well this one is the one that focuses
on desktops, laptops, tablets,

20
00:00:53.257 --> 00:00:56.537
cellphones, the devices that
end users make use of and

21
00:00:56.537 --> 00:01:01.051
typically the devices that you guys
are used to out there in the real world.

22
00:01:01.051 --> 00:01:04.612
Because if you're not an IT then you
probably haven't worked with servers,

23
00:01:04.612 --> 00:01:08.550
you haven't probably worked with
database systems and email servers.

24
00:01:08.550 --> 00:01:09.740
You probably have used a computer.

25
00:01:09.740 --> 00:01:11.040
Well, you're watching this video.

26
00:01:11.040 --> 00:01:13.130
Right?
So you at least have that knowledge.

27
00:01:13.130 --> 00:01:15.440
At that's the type of person
that this is targeted for.

28
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:18.490
And in a workplace,
when you just transition in IT,

29
00:01:18.490 --> 00:01:22.170
you're typically gonna be starting
as help desk, or desktop support.

30
00:01:22.170 --> 00:01:23.750
Right?
That's kind of the entry level

31
00:01:23.750 --> 00:01:25.020
position in IT.

32
00:01:25.020 --> 00:01:27.880
So, you need to be able to
know how to identify and

33
00:01:27.880 --> 00:01:31.460
resolve issues on a Windows machine,
how to do it on a tablet,

34
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:34.340
how to integrate somebody's iPad
into your Windows environment.

35
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:37.260
All right, these are things that you've
got to know how to do out there in

36
00:01:37.260 --> 00:01:40.940
the real world to be a valuable employee,
and that's what the MTA helps to certify.

37
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:45.100
Now, there is more than one MTA that
we need to need to be aware of.

38
00:01:45.100 --> 00:01:46.430
Right?
Let's take a look at Microsoft's web

39
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:47.100
page, real quick.

40
00:01:47.100 --> 00:01:50.937
Cuz they do a great job of explaining what
the MTA is, who it's designed for, but

41
00:01:50.937 --> 00:01:52.984
also highlighting the different tracks.

42
00:01:52.984 --> 00:01:56.563
There's a track for IT infrastructure,
a track for database administrators,

43
00:01:56.563 --> 00:01:57.836
and a track for developers.

44
00:01:57.836 --> 00:01:58.400
Right?

45
00:01:58.400 --> 00:02:02.740
Developers are the people who create
applications, they're programmers.

46
00:02:02.740 --> 00:02:05.620
Database, that's for people who are gonna
be running database servers where we

47
00:02:05.620 --> 00:02:08.370
have large collections of
information that are searchable and

48
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:10.600
enabled to retrieve information from.

49
00:02:10.600 --> 00:02:12.100
But IT infrastructure.

50
00:02:12.100 --> 00:02:17.750
That's our normal IT worker, the person
who is supporting servers, workstations,

51
00:02:17.750 --> 00:02:21.470
routers, switches, the infrastructure
that makes the Internet work.

52
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:24.220
And the infrastructure that makes
your business or your home work.

53
00:02:24.220 --> 00:02:24.720
Right?

54
00:02:24.720 --> 00:02:26.820
Somebody's got to know
how to make that run.

55
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:29.160
These are the people who do it,
IT infrastructure.

56
00:02:29.160 --> 00:02:31.330
And so when we look at the MTA exams,

57
00:02:31.330 --> 00:02:34.970
there's several different exams
based on which track you choose.

58
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:39.050
If you go database, you could go
developer, or if you go IT infrastructure.

59
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:42.040
In IT infrastructure you'll see
there's five different exams

60
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:44.440
based on what it is you
wanna specialize in.

61
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:47.550
Now to get the MTA,
you don't have to take all five exams.

62
00:02:47.550 --> 00:02:49.770
You just have to pass one of them.

63
00:02:49.770 --> 00:02:51.520
So pick the area that you're strong in.

64
00:02:51.520 --> 00:02:53.260
In this series,
we're gonna be doing Mobility and

65
00:02:53.260 --> 00:02:55.290
Device Fundamentals because
that's the most common one.

66
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:58.220
That's the one that most people
are gonna want to start off with.

67
00:02:58.220 --> 00:03:00.960
And from there you might choose
to specialize in other things.

68
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:01.880
Right?

69
00:03:01.880 --> 00:03:05.120
So for example, Daniel,
who'd be doing server administration?

70
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:06.120
>> Server administration?

71
00:03:06.120 --> 00:03:09.240
That will definitely fall under
people that wanna become sysadmins.

72
00:03:09.240 --> 00:03:11.280
They wanna work on the server environment.

73
00:03:11.280 --> 00:03:15.821
They're gonna eventually probably become
an MCSA and hopefully one day an MCSC.

74
00:03:15.821 --> 00:03:19.750
So they can take care of those large
infrastructure, and even design and

75
00:03:19.750 --> 00:03:21.150
develop those things, so

76
00:03:21.150 --> 00:03:24.720
that's probably where you'd want to start
off if that was the goal you had in mind.

77
00:03:24.720 --> 00:03:27.230
Other than that though you would just,
like Don said,

78
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:29.510
pick your specialty,
want to get into security?

79
00:03:29.510 --> 00:03:30.890
Jump in that security track.

80
00:03:30.890 --> 00:03:33.824
If you wanted to just get your
feet wet in device mobility?

81
00:03:33.824 --> 00:03:36.866
That's where we're at today, that's
the one you'd want to jump on on that.

82
00:03:36.866 --> 00:03:39.553
>> Yep, and when you take a look
at Server Administrator or

83
00:03:39.553 --> 00:03:41.612
you take a look at Security Fundamentals,

84
00:03:41.612 --> 00:03:45.330
these are typically people that
already have an exposure to IT.

85
00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:47.650
They've been working in desktop support or
something and

86
00:03:47.650 --> 00:03:49.660
they wanna move up to the next tier.

87
00:03:49.660 --> 00:03:52.600
They wanna move over to that
sysadmin side or whatever.

88
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:54.240
And so start moving in to
some of these other ones.

89
00:03:54.240 --> 00:03:55.700
Right?
Network fundamentals,

90
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:58.810
if you're dealing with networking,
TCP/IP-based networks, IPv6,

91
00:03:58.810 --> 00:04:01.650
that kind of stuff falls in there,
but mobility and

92
00:04:01.650 --> 00:04:03.940
device fundamentals,
that's the one we're gonna tackle.

93
00:04:03.940 --> 00:04:06.860
Now, I mentioned you only have to
pass one exam to get your MTA, so

94
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:08.570
you can pass any one of these,
and you get it.

95
00:04:08.570 --> 00:04:12.270
The other thing is, if you wanna move
onto the MCSA like Daniel mentioned,

96
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:14.260
the MTA is not a prerequisite.

97
00:04:14.260 --> 00:04:17.610
So if you already have this knowledge,
you are not forced.

98
00:04:17.610 --> 00:04:19.110
You are not obliged to take this exam.

99
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:20.700
You can skip it.
You can just move right past and

100
00:04:20.700 --> 00:04:22.470
go straight to the MCSA if you want.

101
00:04:22.470 --> 00:04:26.204
But if you're just getting started in IT,
the MSCA is really hard.

102
00:04:26.204 --> 00:04:26.940
All right?

103
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:30.250
It takes a lot of work and
I'm not saying the MTA is easy,

104
00:04:30.250 --> 00:04:33.610
I'm just saying that the MTA is
designed for somebody getting started.

105
00:04:33.610 --> 00:04:36.560
The MCSA is not, it's designed for
somebody that's already in there.

106
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:39.300
So, make sure you place
yourself in the right position.

107
00:04:39.300 --> 00:04:42.580
If you're already started,
if you're already in IT,

108
00:04:42.580 --> 00:04:43.740
the MTA might be a little boring for you.

109
00:04:43.740 --> 00:04:45.050
It might be beneath your skill set.

110
00:04:45.050 --> 00:04:47.411
It looks good on the resume, so
maybe that's what you're looking for.

111
00:04:47.411 --> 00:04:49.454
But, don't feel obliged to do it.

112
00:04:49.454 --> 00:04:52.720
All right, now let's look at
the 368 exam specifically.

113
00:04:52.720 --> 00:04:56.580
If we jump into that exam, you'll see
that there's a couple of basics here.

114
00:04:56.580 --> 00:04:59.300
It's $115, so it's not an expensive exam.

115
00:04:59.300 --> 00:05:01.970
That's US dollars, it's different for
different countries.

116
00:05:01.970 --> 00:05:04.910
And you can take the exam at
a number of different places.

117
00:05:04.910 --> 00:05:08.550
Any Certaport location,
which a lot of colleges,

118
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:11.775
community colleges, secondary schools,
a lot of them are Certaport locations.

119
00:05:11.775 --> 00:05:15.340
But if there aren't any of those,
you can use Pearson View.

120
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:18.500
Pearson View has testing
centers all over the world.

121
00:05:18.500 --> 00:05:19.730
They're a third party provider.

122
00:05:19.730 --> 00:05:22.430
They provide tests for
all sorts of different exams.

123
00:05:22.430 --> 00:05:26.190
And if you go to their site,
you can actually do a center search for

124
00:05:26.190 --> 00:05:27.130
a location.

125
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:28.590
Daniel, what's a city we can use?

126
00:05:28.590 --> 00:05:30.120
>> Let's try Gainesville, Florida.

127
00:05:30.120 --> 00:05:30.710
>> All right.

128
00:05:30.710 --> 00:05:32.830
We can take up Gainesville, Florida.

129
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:34.640
And we'll just do a quick search here.

130
00:05:34.640 --> 00:05:36.470
And you can search anywhere in the world.

131
00:05:36.470 --> 00:05:37.680
Right?
Paris, France, whatever.

132
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:40.650
And it's gonna give you a list of all
the different locations that are out

133
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:42.490
there that are Pearson View Centers.

134
00:05:42.490 --> 00:05:44.010
So we can go and take that exam.

135
00:05:44.010 --> 00:05:47.341
So as far as taking the exam,
they've really removed an obstacle there.

136
00:05:47.341 --> 00:05:49.190
Right?
It's pretty easy to find a location to go

137
00:05:49.190 --> 00:05:50.520
and take the exam.

138
00:05:50.520 --> 00:05:54.090
The hard part is what you need to
know before you go and take the exam.

139
00:05:54.090 --> 00:05:54.590
Right?

140
00:05:54.590 --> 00:05:58.070
So fortunately Microsoft posts their
exam objectives right here, and

141
00:05:58.070 --> 00:06:00.090
this is what we've
structured our show off of.

142
00:06:00.090 --> 00:06:03.300
So our show is going to basically go
through from start to finish tackling

143
00:06:03.300 --> 00:06:06.200
all of these objectives to make sure that
you guys have the information you need to

144
00:06:06.200 --> 00:06:07.520
be successful.

145
00:06:07.520 --> 00:06:10.230
Some of these might be areas you
already know, some might be areas that

146
00:06:10.230 --> 00:06:13.080
are completely new to you, so
this is your chance to get that exposure.

147
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:13.761
All right,

148
00:06:13.761 --> 00:06:18.543
well the first exam objective area is
just understanding device configurations.

149
00:06:18.543 --> 00:06:19.380
All right?

150
00:06:19.380 --> 00:06:20.850
And what this boils down to is,

151
00:06:20.850 --> 00:06:25.170
if I give you a Windows computer,
do you know how to do a basic setup on it?

152
00:06:25.170 --> 00:06:30.060
Things like changing the screen saver time
out, changing power management settings,

153
00:06:30.060 --> 00:06:33.280
setting up device encryption,
all the things we do when we get

154
00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:36.700
a brand new computer and we wanna make
it our own, kinda customize it our way.

155
00:06:36.700 --> 00:06:38.475
Those are the things that we
need to be familiar with.

156
00:06:38.475 --> 00:06:40.330
Right?
And this is end-user stuff,

157
00:06:40.330 --> 00:06:44.320
things that most end users are already
doing if you've had exposure to it.

158
00:06:44.320 --> 00:06:48.790
So basic device configurations and
getting those in place.

159
00:06:48.790 --> 00:06:52.010
The next objective Is understanding
data access and management.

160
00:06:52.010 --> 00:06:53.860
We have a lot of data on our computers.

161
00:06:53.860 --> 00:06:55.390
Right?
Documents, pictures,

162
00:06:55.390 --> 00:06:57.100
music files, whatever.

163
00:06:57.100 --> 00:06:59.010
We need to make sure that
those are secured, so

164
00:06:59.010 --> 00:07:02.400
that only the people we want
to have access do have access.

165
00:07:02.400 --> 00:07:04.400
Right?
We need to kinda keep that trimmed down.

166
00:07:04.400 --> 00:07:08.110
So in this section we cover things
like how to apply file permissions,

167
00:07:08.110 --> 00:07:11.550
how to restrict access, how to share
the files and folders on the network.

168
00:07:11.550 --> 00:07:14.070
Right?
We wanna make sure that people can get to

169
00:07:14.070 --> 00:07:16.210
that information, but
that it's done in a secure manner.

170
00:07:18.370 --> 00:07:20.410
The third objective is Device Security.

171
00:07:20.410 --> 00:07:23.260
Now I kind of already mentioned
security with device access.

172
00:07:23.260 --> 00:07:25.420
But here,
it goes beyond just files and folders.

173
00:07:25.420 --> 00:07:28.160
Here, we talk about things
like the Windows Firewall and

174
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:31.060
how we can control access over
the network and protect our machine.

175
00:07:31.060 --> 00:07:33.730
We're talking about
multi-factor authentication.

176
00:07:33.730 --> 00:07:36.160
We wanna stop people from
logging in to our computer,

177
00:07:36.160 --> 00:07:38.706
unless they have the valid
credentials to get in there.

178
00:07:38.706 --> 00:07:41.144
And we wanna protect our system
in the event that it gets stolen.

179
00:07:41.144 --> 00:07:42.120
Right?

180
00:07:42.120 --> 00:07:45.580
I wanna know that if somebody steals
my laptop, that my data is still safe,

181
00:07:45.580 --> 00:07:46.530
even though I lost my laptop.

182
00:07:46.530 --> 00:07:49.880
And so, those are some of the things that
we take a look at in device security.

183
00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:54.220
Then, we've got an important section,
because more and

184
00:07:54.220 --> 00:07:55.440
more services are moving this way.

185
00:07:55.440 --> 00:07:57.290
We're gonna talk about Cloud Services.

186
00:07:57.290 --> 00:08:00.284
Now the cloud is a term that gets
throw on around quite a bit and

187
00:08:00.284 --> 00:08:02.238
it means a number of different things.

188
00:08:02.238 --> 00:08:05.210
But what we're gonna do is take a look
at it from the standpoint of a normal

189
00:08:05.210 --> 00:08:07.230
end user, and
what cloud services mean to them.

190
00:08:07.230 --> 00:08:07.990
Right?

191
00:08:07.990 --> 00:08:11.290
So what are some cloud applications they
can use, how they can leverage things,

192
00:08:11.290 --> 00:08:14.169
like Windows Azure or Microsoft Intune.

193
00:08:14.169 --> 00:08:16.300
Right?
Different features like that and

194
00:08:16.300 --> 00:08:18.490
how we can implement those for a business.

195
00:08:20.320 --> 00:08:23.270
And then lastly, this one,
Enterprise Mobility.

196
00:08:23.270 --> 00:08:28.020
Enterprise Mobility is basically saying,
it used to be that if you had a computer

197
00:08:28.020 --> 00:08:31.460
for a company, the company provided
the computer, it was a company machine.

198
00:08:31.460 --> 00:08:34.035
But in today's world,
we have a lot of bring your device.

199
00:08:34.035 --> 00:08:35.410
Right?
People bring their own stuff,

200
00:08:35.410 --> 00:08:37.610
their own cellphone,
their own tablet, their own laptop,

201
00:08:37.610 --> 00:08:40.040
and they wanna connect it
to a business computer.

202
00:08:40.040 --> 00:08:41.300
So how do we do that safely and

203
00:08:41.300 --> 00:08:44.820
securely where we can still manage it and
keep our environment safe?

204
00:08:44.820 --> 00:08:47.990
How do we manage our own mobile devices?

205
00:08:47.990 --> 00:08:51.050
And how do we manage the ones that
our employees are bringing in?

206
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:53.550
So we get a chance to take a look
at some of the obstacles there and

207
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:57.610
some of the solutions that we have, like
work folders and Azure remote apps and

208
00:08:57.610 --> 00:09:01.630
technologies that can let us safely
participate in that type of environment.

209
00:09:02.950 --> 00:09:06.390
So those are the five main objective
areas inside of the MTA exam.

210
00:09:06.390 --> 00:09:08.330
They cover some really good stuff.

211
00:09:08.330 --> 00:09:10.960
And Microsoft is not looking for
you to be an expert.

212
00:09:10.960 --> 00:09:14.446
You're not supposed to be a super wizard
with 20 years of industry experience.

213
00:09:14.446 --> 00:09:15.267
You're getting started.

214
00:09:15.267 --> 00:09:16.090
Right?

215
00:09:16.090 --> 00:09:19.280
So a lot of these are just making sure
that you're familiar with the topic.

216
00:09:19.280 --> 00:09:22.780
Not necessarily how to implement and
create that structure.

217
00:09:22.780 --> 00:09:25.820
For that,
that's where we jump into the MCSA and

218
00:09:25.820 --> 00:09:28.780
we start tackling how do we actually build
all this great stuff that we talked about.

219
00:09:30.280 --> 00:09:32.150
So that's basically it for
the exam objectives.

220
00:09:32.150 --> 00:09:35.610
We talked a little bit about the exam
cost as well as where you can take it.

221
00:09:35.610 --> 00:09:38.310
And we talk about the MTA
certification in general.

222
00:09:38.310 --> 00:09:41.150
At this point you guys should have pretty
good picture of what we're gonna cover.

223
00:09:41.150 --> 00:09:44.978
So if this sounds interesting, if it
sounds exactly like what you're looking

224
00:09:44.978 --> 00:09:47.530
for, then you're in the right place,
stay tuned,

225
00:09:47.530 --> 00:09:49.564
we've got our episode starting up next.

226
00:09:49.564 --> 00:09:56.309
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to configure some of the common device options in a Windows desktop environment. Here they explain and demonstrate the benefits of using a Microsoft Account to login to all of your Windows devices. Also covered is the Control Panel and System options that give you the ability to adjust your system devices.
episodes.title: Configure Device Options

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the ways in which you can customize and configure the desktop settings in the Windows 8.1 operating system. Here you'll learn how to adjust the tiles in the Start Menu, see how different profiles can have different settings for personalization, and how to make settings for entire groups of users through Group Policy.
episodes.title: Configure Desktop Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the importance of keeping your PC secure by keeping your apps, software, and Windows operating system up-to-date. Here you'll see you how use the Windows Update service to keep your Windows OS patched and optimized as well as some of your device drivers. Also covered is performing App updates.
episodes.title: Configure Updates

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don jump into the topic of Local Storage. They get started by explaining how you can create a large storage system by stringing a bunch of disks together(JBOD) and then moving into more sophisticated solutions like Microsoft's Storage Pools and Storage Spaces.
episodes.title: Storage Part 1

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don help you understand the different filesystems offered in the Windows OS environment. They detail the attributes of the FAT, FAT32, NTFS, and ReFS filesystems; comparing and contrasting how each may be utilized by you in your specific setting.
episodes.title: Storage Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the exciting world of File and Print sharing. They begin by explaining the permissions utilized by the New Technology File System(NTFS) as well as share permissions and how they are applied to define access to a resource. They then move into the different ways in which you can share resources between local and network users via Microsoft HomeGroups, mapped network drives, and shared printers.
episodes.title: File and Print Sharing

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don introduce us to printer sharing. They begin with sharing a locally attached printer for other users on the network to use. They also detail how to manage users' permissions on the printer for delegating tasks.
episodes.title: File and Print Sharing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Don break down the technologies behind NTFS and shared permissions. Don demonstrates how to set the permissions on a folder for a user to access, modify, and create new documents. He also explains the ability to block or allow permissions to trickle down.
episodes.title: File and Print Sharing Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain some of the ways that you can secure data using common encryption methods. The start with Microsoft's built-in solutions; the Encrypting File System(EFS) and BitLocker which can be used to encrypt either single files or entire hard drives. Then they explore encryption for data on the move using Virtual Private Networks(VPN), certificates, and SSL.
episodes.title: Data Encryption

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the differences between the concepts of the Internet, and intranet, and an extranet. They then explain the Windows Firewall for protecting you as you move from one network type to another. Lastly they explore the topic of cloud networks.
episodes.title: Device Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don describe the concept of authentication and explain the methods commonly used to that end. Methods like passwords, biometrics, and multifactor authentication are detailed as well as smart cards and Windows Rights Management Services. They also introduce you to the many types of malware that threaten computer systems; both how to differentiate and how to avoid them. Some of the malware types discussed are viruses, trojan horses, spyware, and adware. Then they show you how to avoid, and if need be, disinfect these hazards by utilizing antivirus solutions like Windows Defender.
episodes.title: Device Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie define and contrast the different types of cloud services offered today. Here they explore cloud solutions for storage services, Productivity services, communications services, and search services.
episodes.title: Cloud Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore one of Microsoft's cloud based computer management suites called Intune. Here they show you Intune's capabilities for deploying software, modifying location settings, and even selectively removing apps, software, or the Intune client itself. They also describe Microsoft Azure, which is an enterprise cloud solution. Here they show you how to use Azure to deploy virtual servers and workstations as an extension to your physical environment. They explain how Azure is a great solution for disaster recovery, redundancy, and fault tolerance.
episodes.title: Cloud Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain Identity services inside a Microsoft environment, specifically Windows Server Active Directory, Azure Active Directory, and Federation Services. They also explain the concept and implementation of using a Microsoft Account, which allows you to be you no matter what device you're signed into. They also discuss the idea of business data access. Accessing company data from anywhere, especially outside of the business network, is commonplace anymore. Microsoft has deployed solutions like the Company Portal in Intune, Work Folders in Active Directory, and Azure RemoteApp to enable that access to the end user.
episodes.title: Enterprise Mobility

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don introduce you to the concept of the BYOD, or Bring Your Own Device, environment. As more and more personal devices are being used to access private resources, we can use Microsoft solutions to help safely integrate those devices and users. Here we look at methods like virtualization, dynamic access control policies, and Windows Rights management to help make that goal a reality.
episodes.title: Enterprise Mobility Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Wes introduce Windows RT. They discuss some of the limitations to managing Windows RT devices in an enterprise network through traditional mechanisms. They demonstrate how to manage a Windows RT device through Microsoft Intune. They explore the administrative roles that can be delegated in Microsoft Intune. They also take a look at the compliance and configuration policy processing and explain the results of policy conflicts.
episodes.title: Windows RT

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Wes demonstrate how to implement mobile device management of Windows 8 and 8.1 Phone devices. They explain how to enroll Windows 8.1 Phones into Microsoft Intune for mobile device management (MDM). They talk about configuration and compliance policies as well as discussing policy conflicts. They also dive into retiring devices and wiping company data from the after its removed from Microsoft Intune.
episodes.title: Windows Phone
